Drugs + transcendental philosophy + Tokyo + Paz de la Huerta. These elements, when woven together by director Gaspar Noe make for a true example of cinema as high art. That being said, this film cannot really be considered "enjoyable" or even particularly "entertaining." The best way to describe "Enter the Void" is as an experience. Defining a film as an experience is, admittedly, somewhat clichéd, but "Enter the Void" cannot help the fact that its sole descriptor has fallen victim to cliché by the hands of lesser creations. The dreamy floating camera-work that we became acquainted with in "Irreversible" is back this time and it seems to have found its true calling as the viewpoint of a wayward spirit. All of the performances are intensely personal and thoroughly believable. The first person perspectives could easily have been distracting or annoying, but for some reason they work and give the viewer a sense of almost hypnotizing immersion. "Enter the Void" is definitely not a relaxing good-times fun sort of film, but for those in the mood for a sober trip it cannot be missed.Note: Not for the epileptic

Modern times. New times. Times of changes. Often I was wondering where the changes in cinema take place? "Avatar?" I didn't think so. Or another Steven Spielberg thing - well done, but kind of lame? The director stars from yesterday became old, and instead of innovation they put technique. "Enter the void" shows how it looks like, if innovation meets technique. And most of all: The director is brave as hell that he goes for a theme, that is simply impossible to film. Or: It was impossible. "Enter the void" is the first film that is dealing serious with death and reincarnation. Without escaping into metaphors like most films do, when it comes to death. if you look closely you may find incredible beauty in here - but first it is a shock. There is a lot of pain in it. Gaspar Noé doesn't take you by the hand. He kills you, and leaves you alone, floating in timeless space. In "irreversable" a viewer still had the chance to escape. There was still this "actor"-thing: Whatever happened, it was possible to say: This is a film and there are the actors acting. "Enter the void" makes you a soul that observes some few moments of love, in between chaotic life of struggle and pain. When there is a recommendation useful, like "only for open minded people", then for this movie. It is deeply honest, and therefore hard to bare. But if you waited for something that offers you a mirror, "Enter the void" will tell you a lot about your life. Where you come from, where you are, and where you are going to. Even if you are not dealing with drugs ;)

Review title: A Heady Trip through the Eye of the Camera
Review_body: Enter the Void has sharply divided critics. Detractors loathe its "puerile" ideas, its banality, it contrived effects, whereas its advocates praise its technical photographic brilliance, its use of neon color, its representation of Tokyo nightlife.They are both wrong. The brilliance of this flawed but innovative film is its camera-work, yes, but not merely for the rolling camera, which is just a technical feat that, as Noé himself said, is obsessively applied. There is probably no film in history that has depended so thoroughly on the crane shot. No, the brilliance of this film lies in its reduction of the narrative to a purely photographic perspective. The camera empties out the film until it is the only light shining into the void. Movies are still very much indebted to the formal characteristics of the theater -- script, plot, dialog, character development, and so on. Noé tosses that all out. If you are looking for character growth, plot, verbal spark, you will be disappointed. The characters, though quite forlorn and tragically tinged, are banal and unchanging; the dialog, delivered in a monotone, is uninspired and uninformative; the plot is not really a plot at all, insofar as the action is connected only through the traveling camera rather than through an inexorable chain of cause and effect. The story is a bare bones melodrama, nothing more.The film titillates us with the idea that Oscar, who has been loaned a copy of the Tibetan Book of the Dead, is playing out the motif of reincarnation and is reborn in the end. The film begins inside his head, the camera establishing a point of view perspective to which it relentlessly, even annoyingly adheres until Oscar is shot and killed in a drug bust. The camera then leaves his body and floats above the city spying on the people in Oscar's life from above. It is implied that he is living out the story of the Tibetan Book: he is temporarily disembodied and seeking the means to be reincarnated. But it dawns on you after a while that this motif is nothing more than a metaphor for the camera and that the only subjectivity of any significance is that of the camera – or the movie goer. The camera is not a stand in for the protagonist; it is the protagonist. The idea occurred to Noé when he saw Robert Montgomery's Lady in the Lake, a 1947 film shot entirely in a first-person perspective. But here that first person perspective becomes an empty subjectivity devoid of personal characteristics once Oscar is dead. The camera continues to visit the various people he knows and also revisits crucial moments in his past – the death of his parents in a car crash, the separation in childhood from his sister, and the immediate events leading up to his death. But the camera is impersonal. It looks over his shoulder, as if he himself were looking back at his past self, but the irony, as well as the thematic thrust of the film is that Oscar is good and truly dead. There is nothing but a void, which we fill with our sentimental dreams and creative spirit.In the press kit Noé claimed that "The main subject of the film is rather the sentimentality of mammals and the shimmering vacuity of the human experience." At one point, Oscar visits his friend Alex, a painter rooming with another guy who is building a model of Tokyo's nightclub district. Oscar shines a light through the windows of the model Love Hotel and remarks that it would be fun to be able to hover above the city and peek in the windows, spying on everyone making love. This is eventually just what the camera does. The utter weightlessness of the characters strips the film of any metaphysical pretense. There is just the void. You enter the void and depart. The cycle of rebirth is merely an illusion that derives from the pattern of birth and death. Noé has said that "it's not the story of someone who dies, flies and is reincarnated, it's the story of someone who is stoned when he gets shot and who has an intonation of his own dream." Noé emphatically rejects any religious interpretation and does not himself believe in any religion. It is an utterly unsentimental take on life, birth and regeneration of the species (not the individual). Oscar's sister gives birth at the end of the film, and the birth of her child is merged with the birth of Oscar – but this is not rebirth: just successive generation.This is what gives weight to what otherwise would be a merely visually interesting journey or a nihilistic bit of iconoclasm; the film acquires power from the tension between our hopes, our dreams, and the brutal reality of sudden, unwilled life and death that mark the boundaries of the void. The theme and the camera-work are one. The camera is the film, it is what gives substance to the void. And each of the viewers is invited in; each of the viewers is a camera too, filming its journey through the void. Once Alex is dead, you take his place.The camera is both the engine of the film and its means of Kathartic release. The most significant aspect of its Tokyo is not the neon urban jungle of sex clubs and drug dealers, but the tight, tiny womb like cubicles in which everyone exists that are so claustrophobic as to make you queasy. The final image in the film is a birth, and that sudden rush from the suffocating canal is itself a metaphor for the release that is obtained through the camera's ability to travel over and through these constricting spaces. If there is any sentimentality at all, it is the belief in the liberating power of art despite or perhaps because of its struggle to imbue the void with meaning by giving it form.

Like no other movie, and that is really saying something. An otherworldly experience. Sad but also revelatory. Let's be honest, this has to be one of the deepest films ever made. The scope, the reach is just amazing.

Patience. It's something that's quickly eroding at the dawn of my generation. I do not mean this as a criticism. Times change. But in our age of accessing information so quickly, we can often find ourselves just "getting to the point" these days. I will start off by saying that this film requires patience. While you may actually get the point of this movie rather quickly, the ride itself is a long winded sermon about the sanctity of life itself."Do you believe in reincarnation?" is the setup of the entire concept of what could be considered Noe's magnum opus. The driving force here is that procreation is driven by empathy. The need to connect with someone on the deepest level to create life.It is filmed entirely from the perspective of Oscar, the film's protagonist, who dies unexpectedly from a series of unfortunate events. What follows after is a deeply personal journey of his spirit's observations post-life. He must witness the humanity of those he loves most, laid bare. His willingness to forgive these transgressions ultimately leads to his rebirth, and the fulfillment of his promise to his sister.While Noe's films can be considered very personal in a way, and deal with taboo that we often stride over with rapidity, it serves well for those willing to receive it. If one were willing to give these ideas a chance, and explore them with said patience, they'll find something in a film that very few directors can provide us today... life itself. While such introspection can cause discomfort in those that expect merely escapism from a film, here provided is an introspective and soulful existentialism that dives deep into the nature of human forgiveness and retribution.A film that is beautiful visually, musically, and humanely. I guarantee that you will not experience another film like it, and it will resonate for some time.

I think I never saw a movie that is more self-indulgent than this. There is a slightest fragment of a good idea in this movie, and an original style, but the director (Gaspar Noe) just doesn't know where to stop. One could randomly cut out 1 full our of this movie, and everyone would be better with it. I can't emphasize this enough. Every. Single. Scene. Goes on for far too long. The movie is also very obvious, and treats its audience as idiots. I can't count how many times I wanted to just stand up and shout at the screen "we get it!!!". But sadly, in our world, this garbage exists, with a director that flew way too close to the sun. And I sure wish all the artsy people who pump this movie's and director's ego and rating, would just stop giving them oral pleasure (self censored), so we can actually see some good movies from this dude.

Whilst it is very well made and many scenes are compelling - roughly half the movie is filler with dragging landscape shots and certain scenes repeating three or four times throughout. I'd recommend it as a depressing peer into the abyss but don't expect anything too cohesive plot wise.

I enjoyed it, VERY much. The colors and the camera-work are mesmerizing, feels like everything is real although everything feels to be surreal. It was really a mind-blower, but in a slow, calm and gorgeous way. The length of the movie gives justice, every second is either beautiful or interesting. I HAD to light some cigarettes twice during the movie, but not because it is boring, but because you just feel like you MUST light some cigarettes. It is all about the atmosphere this movie has. It is a bit art film, but that's only a good thing. I recommend it to everyone who want to watch something out of the ordinary, watch something messy yet well-understandable, and just want to chill out a bit, perhaps.

Review title: Flying camera shows us the void that is the human experience, and moral relativists hated it for that reason
Review_body: Most walked out disgusted, some repulsed by what they were seeing. There was one person to blame for this: Gaspar Noé, the director, who had previously tortured audiences with his shocking powerhouse Irreversible (aka Monica Bellucci getting raped by a disgusting gay pimp and getting avenged by Vincent Cassel and friend via fire extinguisher blow to the head to the power of 21, all with nausea- inducing imagery and horrific violence). But don't shoot the messenger: for Gaspar's film was merely acting as a window into the void that is the human experience. I don't know what high level (?) acting some were expecting on this film, it's not like regular individuals have Broadway-levels of expression or emotion on display whenever something happens to them, there are real life dead beats out there. Plus, it's not the acting that takes center stage here, it's the visuals, the seductively nightmarish neon splashes of immorality and fever dream- ish visuals. It's painful and sometimes dull to watch not because it's a badly written piece of cinema, but because it shows us the true nature of human interaction, the black hole that is life (especially if you're an incestuous junkie with nothing better to do than getting high and leading a life of crime, sin, and overall meaninglessness). With this film, you are entering the void, and you may never return from it. An assault on the senses, a masochistic experience, but a very educational one at that. Weirdly enough, this film did not make me into an edgy nihilist, but instead taught me (in its own intense way) to appreciate life more than I did before, and compelled me to make the most of it. Definitely not a film for the faint of heart, the easily offended, or the snobbish progressive that can't comprehend that debauchery and moral relativism do not equal happiness, fulfillment, or meaning (they can't stand licentiousness being cast in a negative light, and will promptly jump to condemn the film for being too "judgemental" and "self-righteous", as if indulging in selfish hedonism without any moral guidance wasn't a bad thing in and of itself).
I recommend this movie for everyone. The way it is filmed and the whole plot is fantastic. It really gets you.
Love it. This movie can be confusing some time. But the hole movie is stunning!

I like a good popcorn flick as well, but movies like this, that just have the balls to take this medium and push it, just well, the brass balls on the filmmaking team. Review title: Beautiful film, but very drawn out.
Review_body: Although the movie is told in a very unconventional way and contains some excellent camera-work, the length of the film and acting left me feeling frustrated. By the end of the last "scene" I was pretty much just mad and talking/yelling at the movie for being so ridiculously bloated with footage. This movie could easily have been 40 minutes shorter and by that effect have been rated much higher by myself. Noe should have taken some constructive criticism from editors out there and cut out some of the scenes in the film. Sure a film can be more than 3 hours long (this one is "only" 2 hours and 40 minutes), but that requires more story and scenes need to contain more importance towards the plot. By comparison the film Novocento is around six hours total and while slightly frustrating, the length could be justified in it's depth of plot and acting. This movie depicts one day in the two lead characters life, plus a number of flashbacks to their childhood, used to explain their complex relationship. I liked the way the main characters actions are explained later in the film, making us sympathize with him later on in the film, but this does, as I've mentioned earlier in this review, not excuse the run time of this particular flick.

Review title: A neon ride into the grown up world
Review_body: This was my first film at the Stockholm Film Festival, I don't mean to brag but Gaspar Noé got to use my umbrella when the reporters took photos of him in the rain, never going to touch that umbrella again...First I have to say "Enter The Void" technical masterpiece. The use of the camera is creative and splendid and makes the whole movie as a roller coaster ride. The special effects are really, really special. I got hooked on these technical superiority's in "Enter The Void" that I got all thrilled down my spine. Watching it at the cinema really gave it an incredible touch. The sound was ear piercing and in some scenes it made me jump in the seat. It could go almost half and hour without any dialog, just remarkable scenes and CGI. You could think by this description it's a joyful and happy movie, but it's really not. It's dark, sea bottom dark. This movie have everything all parents wants to keep away from their children. I just get the feelings this movie would get so censored in America it would be a whole other film when showed over the ocean. But censoring this movie is fatal and would kill it. I certainly hope everyone is going to get sucked into the void just as I did.It was a great experience, I can't deny it, but what made me put an 8/10 was the length. Sometimes Gaspar really could have made some shots shorter, there were unnatural long phases that were totally unnecessary. So that's why I give it an eight. Other then that I see no faults in this masterpiece. Go watch as soon as it shows up in a cinema close to you.

I love how different this movie is. The raw emotion shot even with all the blurry scenes is so beautifully done.
I do think there is way to much sex. Thought it's a fun ride and interesting, very real life and a fun psychedelic trip just too much sex

This movie starts out in a style unlike most and you feel drawn into Tokyo and the flashing lights, as you see life from the point of view of our hero Oscar. A young Englishman with an unhealthy hallucinogenic drug habit living with his sister. He has earned enough money to bring her back to his side in Japan through dealing.During the first 90 minutes we are treated to a hallucinogenic trip through Oscars eyes before he departs with his friend Alex to drop drugs off at the local club. We see drama unfold and enjoy the telling of our hero's childhood with his sister before another shock. Cleverly told through flashbacks the story is both intriguing and interesting as we examine their lives together and the effects of their actions. The visuals are amazing and the effects of flying from one scene to another are at first fantastic and dreamlike. However as you drift slowly from one scene to another you can only feel infuriated and frustrated at the plodding between the plot.Still enthralled to find out what will eventually happen I found myself fast forwarding through the last 60 minutes to the story bits. I was rewarded with some scenes of bizarre debauchery in the Love Hotel before the story finale.Having loved being shocked by 'Irreversible' I enjoyed 'Enter the Void' but was frustrated at the overdoing of the visual trips flying over and through buildings for maybe 60 minutes of the 175 minutes. If you don't mind chilling out (possibly with some chemical inducement to help) and just watching a visual masterpiece with a great story interlaced within it this movie is for you. Otherwise just have the fast forward button at the ready. Drug taking, gore, sex, and bizarre but true life acts, combine in a dream like story of life and a vision of death and fantasy. Id give this movie 8 out 10 if it were cut to a more reasonable length.

Would have really liked to have been able to finish this but after thirty minutes of the first person point of view and the screen flickering black every five seconds when the main character blinks, I couldn't watch anymore. Very trippy and psychedelic movie with LOTS of visuals. From what I saw of the movie there is lots of blinking text (opening credits will give you a seizure, not kidding) and bright flashing lights.I don't know, this movie could be good if you're in the right mind set, but I sat down and tried to watch it, I was just miserable.Will update review when I can watch it all.

Without parallel, without precedent, and without a way to compare it.Enter the Void. I have seen 2001, and I've seen all Stanley Kubrick films. I've seen psychedelic films. Nothing really comes close.What really strikes me is how scary and yet beautiful this film was. How disturbing and personal it gets, from time to time. People who have compared this film to Tree of Life, or such other 'subjective' films, are getting close, but this film is still it's own. So disturbing, so nightmarish, and so colorful in a hallucinogenic way, Enter The Void really transcends notions of filmmaking and camera work. It also encapsulates a true out-of-body experience, in which 'death is the ultimate trip'.Not recommended for everyone.
This here is the most visually stunning masterpiece of all time. A movie like no other, its like a dream captured. Impeccably the best movie ever captured.

Review title: Gaspar Noe's most audacious yet alienating work of visual splendor
Review_body: Being a big fan of Gaspar Noe's work I went into Enter the Void with a checklist in my mind of what to expect from him. His films have certain elements that make them work, he uses a distinct style, hardcore sex, unflinching acts of violence, and to bring it all together with some sort of philosophical statement. These things are the quintessential elements of what make I Stand Alone and Irreversible so compelling. However, for me, Enter the Void contain all of these elements but they did not work to create a compelling whole. Perhaps this style does not work due to the fact that Gaspar Noe is wrapped up in his own ego and has forgotten about what made his previous two films so compelling. Irreversible and I Stand Alone feature accessible central characters, Gaspar manages to manipulate the audience into liking these despicable people by giving them human qualities and making them believable with fantastic performances. Here, the Oscar's (the films central character) face is hardly shown and does not seem to convey any sort of emotion, he is usually quite wooden and conveys everything with a bland tone. As an audience we never get a sense of a character and thus made me care less and less about the film as it went on and on. Everyone that Oscar encounters (from Alex to Bruno) feel like they are hollow video game characters who are just there to serve the plot and don't have any sort of humanity. Their performances remove any tension. Lets take the scene before Alex and Oscar go to visit Bruno about buying drugs, Alex tell Oscar about how dangerous Bruno is. That he would drug you and use you for his own sexual satisfaction. You believe this Bruno to be a ruthless man, however, when we arrive at his flat, the scene's atmosphere is calm and rather dry. Bruno doesn't feel like a threat, he never raises his voice or threatens anyone's life (not that he needs to). But we never get this unhinged feeling like we do in Gaspar's other films. I thought the scene would have had more tension if Bruno was played correctly. As Enter the Void goes on and on it becomes tedious and Gaspar seems to to indulging in himself too much, with the constant use of the spinning camera flying over people and the lurid sex. The first 60-90 minutes or so were as compelling as it could get if I got over the bland acting and enjoyed it as Gaspar Noe showing this story and not the characters. Enter the Void is made by someone who knows how to show a totally unique vision in the world where there is nothing but bland action films and I believe that is a strength to the film. Gaspar noes how to create visually striking films which compensate for the poor acting and allow for his style to arrest the audience and cause them to go into state of awe at the images on screen, I know there were points where was compelled periodically due to the way Gaspar had manipulated the camera- work and art direction. The film also explores worthy existential themes of what happens after we die and that were constantly live and a loop where there is no greater place than earth. It works to a point and then after a while I felt where I knew it was going through the contrived use of the Tibetan Book of the Dead,it seemed to serve as an explanation for what was going on in the film, ruined it's audacity and therefore more predictable. Enter the Void is a polarizing film that tries to examine the afterlife and for the most part fails due to poor creation of characters and lack of depth within it's ideas.

The characters were interesting and in both movies somewhat driven insanely, taking the viewer along for a fun ride, with surprises, shock, and great cinematography. You were with them, cared about them even if you hated them.This film fails because it lacks this drive, I could not care less about what happens to those characters (by the way all second rate actors), And when eternal overheads repeat and repeat themselves, pointlessly, it makes you care about the characters even less, and the story is then lost and so is the attention of the viewer.I give it 3 because it was ambitious, but Noe really failed this time, I'll be looking forward to what he does next, once that crap is well behind him.

Review title: Like a 2 and a half hour waking-dream
Review_body: I am a huge fan of the "cult-esque" and more complicated movies, and this film was amazing. The first half hour draws you in with a very realistic first person drug trip. Its not been made out to look "hollywoodized" with unrealistic hallucinations, and they don't make the protagonist look like either a) a horrible, drug abusing thug, or b) the hero with a horrid background who couldn't help but do drugs. He is just made out to be a human being doing drugs. No complications. From there, the protagonist is shot (still high on DMT) and the journey begins. The visuals are brilliant, and although the movie is a stunning journey, there is still a vivid story. The movie, however, has its downsides. Something that seemed to bring me down was the fact that the protagonist and his sister have a relationship border lining incest. The long list of sex scenes at the end does also go on for a bit too long, and seems fairly irrelevant to the plot (especially the end of it.) Overall though, the movie was great. Don't expect a linear story, just watch and be amazed.

Review title: An interesting film that could have been so much more
Review_body: Enter the Void is a flawed, but deeply disturbing and powerful film that will almost certainly stay with you for a very long time. Through the use of superb camera-work, an unnerving ambient score and a powerhouse performance Paz De La Heurta, director Gaspar Noé sucks us into a very dark place. Of course, it is impossible to talk about the film without mentioning its fantastic first person opening sequence, chronicling the last half hour of protagonist Oscar's life. We see him take a strange hallucinogenic drug, before leaving his house and going to meet his friend, all the while being presented with a disjointed, and at times highly existential inner monologue. This scene is, for lack of a better word, astonishing, and more than sets the tone for the surreal nightmare to come. From then on, the camera, perhaps a representation of the protagonist's spirit, moves freely through space and time, never confined to one place, almost as though it were some kind of omniscient being. We are also presented with psychedelic, almost headache inducing strobe lights set against an oppressive red colour palette, which, perhaps in an inferior film, would be no more than a gimmick to masquerade artistic prowess. In this, however, the lighting serves to highlight the despair and misery the characters are living through, as we, like the protagonist watch in horror, unable to save them from their inevitably unpleasant fate. The performances are, in general, pretty good. Nathaniel Brown is convincing as Oscar, playing somebody who, while devoted to his sister's well-being, gives very little regard to the lives of others. The only performance that I would call bad comes from Cyril Roy, playing his friend, who, intentionally or otherwise, comes across as detached from the situation around him, and unable to speak without sounding slurred. The standout, however, comes from the aforementioned Paz De La Heurta, playing Oscar's damaged sister Linda, the emotional anchor of the film. She portrays someone who, though innocent at first, becomes increasingly aware, and disturbed, at the nightmarish situation she's in, and increasingly desperate for some sort of escape. All this is done with a raw emotional intensity that you simply would not see in a more mainstream film. This film is, of course, far from perfect. Its biggest flaw lies in its borderline excessive run-time, which could have been reduced drastically had Noé removed a few unnecessary scenes, or, alternatively, cut a few short. Around halfway through, we are shown a shortened version of the opening scene again, only without the first person perspective. This could have been shortened quite easily, by showing only the most crucial moments, before moving on. Towards the end, Noé starts recycling and re-purposing the same type of shot, finishing, quite disappointingly, with a visually stunning, though overlong sequence that detracts from the emotional climax of the film. Despite an overstretched run-time and occasional moments of weakness, Enter the Void is essential viewing for anyone interested in surreal, unsettling cinema. Obligatory rating: 8.5/10

Let me say first that this movie does warrant some respect for the very beautiful visuals. This movie is unparalleled in "drug-trip" scenery in it's accuracy. I also enjoy the philosophy behind the movie, the idea, and the acting.However, the positive parts do not lead to a positive whole. Some how, the movie not only takes all of these great elements and makes a boring movie that is a chore to watch from start to finish, but it makes it almost unwatchable thanks to some needless, gratuitous vulgarity. Literally half of the movie has some sort of creepy incest undertones that makes the viewer uncomfortable. While I am an open-minded person that loves horribly vulgar movies, this one just didn't use the shock value correctly. Instead of being an exciting foray into the world of a drug abuser and his death, it seems to be a foray into sexuality and not so much the questions about death, which the movie seems to advertise. I understand the concepts, but it almost seems like the director did not.I can not honestly say I recommend this movie to any one, much in the same way I have difficulty recommending 2001: A Space Odyssey. The concepts of both movies are great, but the momentum is so begrudgingly slow that it almost feels like you are punishing yourself to finish the movie. Don't get me wrong, I still love Kubrick's masterpiece for it's masterful direction despite the chugging momentum, but Enter the Void seems to rely on gimmicky camera tricks and trippy visuals. The lack of a coherent story arc, while suitable for the purposes of the movie, just does not mesh well with the already slow pacing and rather hefty run-time.If this movie was truly in a first person perspective, we'd have to know everything the main character knows for it to function correctly. While we do learn a lot about the character, his family life, his childhood, and his current life, it does not come until you are already confused about some of the characters and annoyed with the pacing.I give it a somewhat harsh 3 out of 10 because it has every good element this movie needed to succeed, but the pacing and over-long run time do not allow adequate use of these elements to return a complete-feeling, satisfying film. Instead, you get a movie that will shock you, bother you, make you uncomfortable, and, most importantly, bore you to death. The pretentiousness here is too thick for me to enjoy.

Review title: A visionary piece of cinematic experimentation, beautiful and dark, dirty and bright
Review_body: "Enter the Void" (2009) the last film of the Argentinian director Gaspar Noé is a very ambitious film of 2h and 41 minutes and the result is a shocking visual and emotional experience, a visionary piece of cinematic experimentation, beautiful and dark, dirty and bright. From the beginning with the amazingly original and shocking opening titles we have already a feel of which kind of monster we are going to be confronted with. We could describe it as "Ghost" meets "Trainspotting" in a psychedelic Tokio of neon lights but it's much more than that because it is the kind of movie that enters your system and stays there for a while, visiting you in dreams and thoughts. With his previous film "Irréversible", Noé showed us his taste for provocation and extreme imagery. There were in there some perverted cinematographic choices, like for instance the fact of having a very shaky camera along the whole film except in one specific scene, where the camera is fixed, which is the scene depicting the rape of Monica Belucci's character, in what we could call an act of utmost depraved voyeurism. But with "Enter the Void" Noé has achieved a much more balanced and mature result. He is very good at digesting and recycling cinematographic references in a inventive way, in "Irréversible" for instance, the fact of telling the story backwards was not of his invention and Christopher Nolan did it before with "Memento" (2000), but Noé adds the technical prowess of doing each fragment as a long shot or "oner", that is a take without any cut. In the first act of "Enter the Void" Noé matches the point of view of the main character with the camera so we see what the character sees, integrating even Oscar's blinking as short blackouts of the screen. This technique is also not new and it was used by Robert Montgomery in "Lady in the Lake" (1947), an experimental film noir that was shot exclusively using this principle to the point that the only moment we see the main character is when he looks at himself in the mirror, same thing in the first part of "Enter the Void". But Noé learned the lesson from "Lady in the Lake" where due to this exclusive perspective there is a lack of identification to the character by the viewer so he uses different methods to show us Oscar's point of view, even in the afterlife. "Enter the Void" has a debt with Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey" and is no surprise since Noé acknowledges him as a big influence and there is a reference to the mentioned film in an abortion scene where we see a fetus echoing the cosmic baby of "2001". Beware this movie is not for the faint of heart and due to strong stroboscopic effects it shouldn't be seen by anyone suffering of epilepsy. Despite many experimental elements in the film it has a very solid narrative structure which helps us to follow it without getting lost. Oscar is a small time dealer in Tokyo trying to make money to bring his young sister Linda from whom he was separated after the tragic dead of their parents in a car accident. He made her a promise when kids that they'll never get apart from each other. They get together but things turn bad, she becomes a pole dancer in a murky club and dates Mario a local gangster and Oscar gets into big trouble because of the drug business which is severely repressed in Japan. Oscar's friend Alex a charismatic painter, has lend him the "Tibetan book of the Dead" which he describes it to him as the experiences that the consciousness has after death, during the interval between death and rebirth. One of the film's main themes is precisely life after death and reincarnation, everything set in an hallucinatory context induced by psychedelic drugs like LSD and DMT. Without wanting to reveal too much of the plot lets just say that the film is not all what it seems and Noé has cleverly made some things fuzzy which helps us to give the movie two main interpretations. There is a key and beautiful scene which is the final one, where the camera adopts first the point of view of a spermatozoon and then the one of a baby when he just comes out of his mother's belly but Noé is smart enough to blur the image, fact that is completely justified due to the point of view of the new born, so we don't really know who the mother is. Thanks to this ambiguity and some other key moments during the film we can elaborate different versions of what really happened. Despite all its violence and darkness, I am really happy about this movie and that there are still some people like Gaspar Noé that have the courage to go where almost nobody dares to go, because thanks to people like him movies as an art go forward. One might not like certain things or be shocked, I for instance didn't like some easy and pretentious Freudian references but it doesn't matter because Noé with this film, with its imperfections (Who wants perfection? Is perfection a human thing?), with its many accomplishments, with its brutal, dirty and dark beauty and precisely because of all that, has achieved a masterpiece that won't be forgotten for long time. Unfortunately this film which had a budget of 13 MUSD didn't managed to recover even one million. How ironic for a film that, in my opinion, will find a place of privilege in the history of movies but it doesn't really matter, what is important is that it exists. I am sure I will watch this movie many times in the future and as with any great movie it will allow me to find new details and ways of interpretation. Thank you Gaspar Noé for making movies better!

The shock and awe coming out of this film must be what it was like coming out of TAXI DRIVER 30 odd years ago - both films not shy to show you the perverse and depraved life of a dark seedy night time city metropolis.Recently reunited with his sister in Tokyo, drug dealer Oscar is shot in a police ambush inside a bar called The Void. When he leaves his body his only concern is to look our for his sister's well being and uphold a pack they made as kids never to leave each other and find a way back to her. What unfolds is a journey seemingly inspired by 'The Tibetan Book of the Dead' that looks like a neon lit life review filled with unfulfilled incestuous sexual wantings, a tragic car crash, city fly bys that zoom down to find glimpses of post shooting moments that his strip club dancer sister, artist friend Alex, and drug taking friend Victor go through following his death as we put the pieces together of what his short life amounted to.It's a roller coaster ride effectively shot entirely from the POV of Oscar; when I left the film and walked out into a wet Soho in London I suddenly wondered if I was still in the film and paranoid that my brain had been transplanted by Oscar's.The film is about 20 minutes too long and indulgent in parts, but a film as visceral, technically amazing and thought provoking as this don't come along often. Go see it.

The Emperors New Clothes is how I would describe this movie. The story line pretty simple, it is essentially about another not to bright loser dealing drugs. As far as it being a technical "masterpiece" clearly some reviewers need to watch a few more movies. Lots of crane and aerial (floating)l tracking shots combine with flashing colours and iTunes (Think Kubrick's 2001) visualizer type imagery does not equal a cinematic masterpiece. Its a story void of any real charter development and there are certainly no characters that one can empathize with. You can have all the flashing colours and floating "dream like" sequences cut together with flash backs, but at the end of the day, if you don't care about the characters or what happens to them, then the movie has failed. No one I watch the movie with cared about any of the characters, in fact the consensus was they were quite lame. So it's back to the floating camera work.Don't get me wrong, it's watchable, almost interesting, but it's a one trick pony of a movie with poor dialogue and shallow characters.

Gasper Noe knows how to make audiences cringe and also make them think. In Enter the Void he takes it a step further and puts us literally into the protagonist's POV. We meet Oscar early on into the film, an American drug dealer living in Tokyo watching over his younger sister. Oscar meets your typical lowlifes and junkies but also trys to find a sort of meaning into life. We watch as he smokes DMT and trips for what feels like an hour but only lasts about thirteen-fifteen minutes and tries to understand the Tibetan Book of the Dead. Little does Oscar know who drug fueled world is about to come crashing down upon him.Oscar is set up by one of his friends while making a deal in a Tokyo club called The Void, while trying to elude cops he is cornered and killed in a bathroom stall. The events that take place afterwards are best left unspoiled.Needless to say this film is violent and gritty but has more heart in my opinion than Noe's last film Irreversible. The idea of reincarnation and a traveling soul fits the style that Noe is trying to accomplish while at the same time not holding the viewers hand and explaining every little detail to them. I found the film to be raw and honest and something that is definitely not for everyone. But if you're in the mood for a film that will make you think and also make you feel like you too are tripping then I strongly recommend checking out this film.

I went to this movie last night at the Toronto Film Festival knowing nothing about Gaspar Noe, bot was I in for a treat... The film start with a strobe-light effect opening credits, which make you feel uneasy right away. It then shows the last 20 minutes or so of the main character Oscars life (all in first person). He is shot during a drug bust. This is where the movie starts to get weird; Oscars "soul" then hovers around and he re-lives his life. The movie shows his life in a disjointed way either showing his childhood or when he is an adult living in Japan. The movie seems like one continuous shot because from one scene to another Oscars "soul" jumps into either a light source or a black hole and then emerges somewhere else and fly's around for awhile until finding the next scene. This makes the movie drag on so much longer, between every scene there is an extra 10 minutes added. After we re-live Oscars life the audience thinks the movie is over, but no it drags on for another two hours. Showing his friends and families lives and how they react to his death, even going as far as showing his sister having a dream of Oscar waking up after being cremated. All just very odd. So the movie was EXTRA SHOCKING. and here are the highlights: we see his sister get an abortion, a dead featus, his parents faces smashed in from a car crash, and his sister getting cummed in from the vagina's perspective. A giant orgy, nipples being sucked on by babies or men in every scene, and a journey inside a aborted fetus. The movie still had its merits. Visually it was AMAZING, i have never seen anything like it before and never will again. It was truly a journey like nothing else. A movie where CGI shows its full potential without the use of giant robots.The director did get a message across, even though it will probably be different for each viewer, but a message about life/death/spirituality.

I actually enjoyed the first hour and a half of this film. It was different... A little over-indulgent for my regular cinematic taste, but a compelling story told in a truly original way. It felt as if deleted scenes had been randomly tacked on to the end of the film; hammering home the "moral" of the film that had already been unsubtly explained throughout the first half.Most annoying bits:The CGI looked well at the beginning, but the "Schlong" shot? Really?I could draw a map of Japan from memory with all those aerial panning shots. 30 seconds to 1 minute shots in between EVERY scene might have been worth watching... if something was actually happening. The scene in the LOVE hotel... sex=rebirth. I get it. I got the talk when I was a pre-adolescent. I do not need shiny lights emanating from ladies private parts to explain it to me visually.I can say with all honesty that as it stands this is quite possibly one of the worst films I've ever seen. Which is a shame because if it was re-edited, I reckon it would be watch-able if not half-decent.

Review title: Objectively showing subjectivity of life - take it however you like
Review_body: Finally i have a favorite director! His name: Gaspar Noé.I've just come home from a screening "Enter The Void". Was thinking about writing this all the way home: I think he achieved an objective portrayal of the subjectivity of life. Just like Andrei Tarkovsky writes about finding bits of life and representing them in film, he has made a film which feels just like life, to me at least. It was full a mix of beauty and sightings of potential and the torture that desire and trauma in real time is.It was the sex scenes that made me think it was objective - an independent as-accurate-as-can-be - observation of the way things are. They were extremely real, practical, changing positions with a blur on the lens as no human is clear-seeing in the heat of the moment. And at the same time I was worried that my interpretation of them was subjective. To me the heterosexual sex was one of necessity, caused by unhealthy stale and needy, dependent, hormone fueled, animal desire, almost an inconvenience something that was in the way of real life. (Refering here to the end (and the middle for Linda- where there is a split look of mental absence) of the sex act in the brothel with Mario.) Sex leads 'the milf' to despair, having gambled her life for empty gratification and game. On the other hand, sex between Linda and 'the flatmate''s girlfriend is carefree and both are present and engaging, both taking and receiving. The same girlfriend seems more nursing/accommodating and selfless than anything else when her and 'the flatmate' are having sex in the Hotel of Love. I wonder if I am projecting... what did other people think of this? I have notices one other review that was concerned with Gaspar seeming to be homophobic...

This is a classic case of a director trying way too hard to be creative or artistic and failing miserably. He attempted to overcome an extremely weak script by replicating visual and sound techniques used by talented artists like Kubrik, David Lynch and Darren Aronofsky. Be assured, he doesn't come close. Anybody who describes this film as psychedelic obviously hasn't seen true psychedelic experimental films. Seven minute sequences of kaleidescope imagery is not psychedelic, its boring, uncreative and cheap to produce. This looks like a very bad student film from a low budget school. I could have edited this film into a decent 15 minute short. As a feature, its just a 2 hour waste of time.

If Irreversible was like a sledgehammer over the viewer's head, with it's grim, violent reality told in strobe light and spiraling camera, then Enter The Void is surely a neon bullet. More colourful, pulsating, feverish and hypnotic than the first film, Void is quite a trip. But where it raises the stakes visually, it's storytelling falls short.This is coming from someone who doesn't 'like' Irreverible as much as admire it's power. It's not an easy film to sit through, and leaves an unshakeable feeling of horror well after it's over. I respect that, along with Noe's directorial talent in delivering it. In 'Void', I experienced a different journey, and one much less concerned with the characters floating through each scene.Like the neon lights of Tokio, the people in this film were simply there; moving in and out of focus, part of the visual landscape. Once the colourful assault entered it's second hour, I found myself checking my watch, looking around the cinema, waiting for it to end. I didn't care about what happened to anyone hovering under each crane shot, I just wanted to straighten out, leave Tokyo, meet another human being instead of being chastised by all the lights. It was like being given a sermon on life and death by an acid freak in a nightclub; I needed a polite way of excusing myself and finding someone else to talk to. But there was no one else, only Noe.Enter The Void is still in a league of it's own, still something wildly original in a universe of cinematic dreariness. It should be seen by anyone prepared to enter the unknown. But my god, how much more could it have been if it found it's footing on earth, as well as in the void?

Review title: Worst movie I have ever seen.
Review_body: It was by far the worst film I have ever seen. Some parts made me feel sick to my stomach due to the disorienting camera work and other do to the content of what was being shown. Visual effects that added to the ill feeling in my stomach where strobing lights, odd fuzzy focus for extended periods, and jumpy transitions. If you have ever masturbated during a period of deep emptiness in your life, the feeling straight after the climax, is the feeling that I was left with after seeing Enter the Void, The First Time. This film is ambitious. It's inventive, genius, powerful and raw. In an incredibly resourceful way. Despite my suspicion the film compensated on a lack of content, with visual shock and delight, which if removed, might reveal only layers of short stacks. Occasionally, this worked against the film. Perhaps distracting the audience too far, diluting the films overall ability to translate.... Furthermore, some moments or sequences in Enter the Void were a little predictable. Possibly flat or boring too. Umm. But that might be it's only flaw. And still, I can't help but be moved and in love with this film for what it is. The film does redeem itself plenty. It's sheer invention and self-assured style, make up for the dolled-up oversupply of visual drama. Enter the Void, and from what I can gather Gaspar Noe himself, would make no apologies for it's moronic leaning toward masculinity. Instead Gaspar might credit himself as responsible for using such a perspective - to explain Love, it's sources, and it's killers, Fear. The film attempts to overcome it's own fears, with courage. Which I think might explains Gaspar's comfort at making such an overtly egocentric and personal piece, choosing to embrace itself (Gaspar and the film), with courage. In doing so the film overcomes or validates it's own nature, through saturation, as opposed to departure rejection, a lack of this embrace both in form and content, would have resulted in a completely different. A film void of the same level of capacity and commitment. All the characters in Enter the Void are burdened by something. And so we're are always looking for an ulterior motive in their actions. Even in Linda (Oscar's sister). The film reminds us of the natural need for Love. And conversely, our ability to dispense it as a false mechanism. As a trip - For tonight, for a week, Something, anything. Please - to fill this void. Overall the film opens a void, which it allows the audience to fill. An experience. A beautifully big one.
An immersive, tense, heartbreaking experience. Oftentimes disgusting... But that's what art is about, isn't it?

Well, I know I have. There's a lot of people that haven't. You'd know if you have. This movie is beautiful, in a kind of non-symmetrical sort of way. You jump in, brain first, to a world of unfamiliarity and colors. It is very intense at first but simmers down into ironically juxtaposed scenes of intense grief and odd sexuality. You are, in fact, the characters in the movie; Broken by life and not given more chances. You know, some are dead before they are born, right? Some are not given even one chance. Twisted and cherry picked from the cold fingers of hush-hush societies with inferiority complexes, the story of this movie highlights the human experience. We are all broken, and we are ultimately alone, but how should we deal with this? Gaspar makes a convincing existentialist argument, not through the concept of rebirth but through the hilarity of it all. You're just a stoned man dreaming before death of some kind of better alternative, but in the end we are forced to face the fact that we are ultimately alone and alone ultimately. Don't think too much about it. Take this or that drug, take your clothes off, it really doesn't matter at all. Make it a habit, and revisit it. Revisit it because you do not want to revisit other things. Shaped by our experiences, we are given a short glimpse of what it is like to REALLY be shaped by our experiences. You will have post-traumatic stress disorder the entire movie, and will relive the fatal car accident that began the endless cycle that is flirting with death. Low self esteem. Goal-less. The pit of the human experience. But in that pit we find a certain joy, or at least hilarity, or at least irony in it all, that maybe can serve as some form of consolation in a world that is uniquely grim, in fact, inhuman. Please enter the void.

Review title: It a work of art. Genius. Watch with headphones or surround sound.
Review_body: Well where to begin?I saw this film about 3 weeks ago and I thought it was pretty decent. Wasn't brilliant but still was pretty decent and my review could of ended there. I was wrong, I was wrong because watch this film whilst you have been... well you know.Any way on second viewing you notice so much more. Things like the fact you can hear the opening them tune pretty much constantly through the film. The visuals just blew me away, I was captivated. I was on the same journey as the protagonist as if I was viewing through my own eyes.The plot on first viewing was pretty weak and the acting left a lot to be desired. But on the second viewing you realise what it is trying to achieve. It's trying to evoke an emotional response. And you soon begin to feel this response which means any thought of plot is no longer need.It isn't a film you would sit down to on a Saturday night with a tub of popcorn. It's something you sit down to with a couple of mates and a...A lot of it takes place in a first person perspective. It really connects us to the protagonist because as he blinks we slowly find that our blinking becomes synced to his. Once again I say... Captivated.The sound technician is a wizard, an artistic genius. There are so many layers to the soundtrack. It's like it was all thought about, all the sounds of Tokyo. There's so many subtle touches that are so easy to miss on the first viewing. It's as if every single sound was planned and thought about and meticulously placed. Maybe I'm reading too into it I doubt it though. The intro music which sounded awful, like cats dying on first viewing transcends any prior knowledge of what a soundtrack should be. It's visual and auditory poetry, a hypnotic ensemble of the senses. There is not a single silent second in the hole experience. That's what I'm defining it as... an experience. I say it again, captivated.I really can not do it enough justice in petty words. During the death scene there are only what I can describe as binaural tones, a tone when played at a certain frequency tunes the brain so to speak. After the death scene the visuals kick up the gear. He gets sucked into this light but he rejects it, he's not ready to leave. He made a promise to watch over his sister. As you have heard the protagonists thoughts up till now you have had a guiding voice; but once he dies these thoughts stop and you find that your's do too, and this turns into meditative trance and all you have to go on are your primal sense of sight and audio. There a hints of incestuous feelings between the brother and sister this is evident in a few scenes.A psychologist could write a thesis studying the brother sister relationship and the affect losing their parents had on them. I'm going to leave it there I think. Not much more can be said about how genius this film is. It's got so many individual layers all working to get an emotional response.This isn't just a film. This is an experience.

Review title: Wow what a head f#@k, I should point out I dropped acid before this movie
Review_body: I don't even know where to start with this film, I recently tried DMT and a friend recommended that I watch this movie. I love a good movie on acid so I decided to chuck this on. Right from from the start I was captivated, the credits at the start set the feel of the movie, the mind-state of the main character is captured amazingly, I could almost feel the out of body scene. It shocked and intrigued me on a level I have never felt before, it was both disturbing but captivating. The audio is perfect, the echo effects, the music kicking in at just the right moment. It captures the feeling perfectly, making you feel confused and uncomfortable at the same time, and the visual effects and hallucinations are mind blowing. After trying DMT myself I struggled to express what I saw as it was by far the strangest and darkest place I have been, all perfectly fine if you are comfortable on psychedelics. Not for the faint hearted. I did find comfort in the fact it only lasts 10 mins or so. Gasper hit the nail on the head with movie and the experience left me speechless for at least an hour while my brain processed what I had just witnessed. They say never judge a person till you walk a mile in their shoes, this is one of those times, I believe you can appreciate while sober, however I believe the full experience requires a little help along the way. Absolutely recommend for any fan of psychedelics, or any person curious of their effects as it is hard to put into words. In a word WOW!!!

Review title: Some potential, wasted by the director's self-indulgence.
Review_body: Enter the Void begins as a regular day in the life of Oscar, a small- time American drug dealer, eking out an existence of some sort in a dodgy area of Tokyo. His sister, a more recent arrivee to Japan, works as a stripper in the same neighbourhood. As children, brother and sister were orphaned in a car crash. Whenever director Gaspar Noé seems to think we may be in danger of forgetting this fact, he treats us to a yet another flashback in which we relive the crash. This happens four, five, six times -- so many times that the viewer will begin to question if it ever will stop happening. This film seems interminable at times. Oscar has been reading the Tibetan Book of the Dead, which is, like, totally far out, maan. It says that when you die, your spirit leaves your body and floats around for a while, then you see your own life in fast-forward, then you see for bright lights for a while, then you are shown some possible futures, one of which you will be reborn into. This is the cue for the drug bust by the Japanese police, in which Oscar is shot dead. (Spoiler: during the "my life flashing before my eyes" segment, you will spend about 45 minutes staring at the back of the main character's head.)If Noé had had the self-discipline to edit his film properly and to keep it internally consistent, this could have been an interesting cinematic experiment, with plenty of cult potential. But the reality of the thing is a 160(!)-minute contrived, incoherent, embarrassing, bottomlessly pretentious and bottomlessly irritating mess.The film runs utterly out of ideas ideas no later than 90 minutes in, at which point the viewer merely begins to wait for it to end. The last 30 minutes or so are perhaps some of the most exasperating cinema ever produced -- not merely boring or repetitious, but downright aggressively, militantly shitty movie-making. And this is the "short" version of the film -- the director's cut apparently runs well over three hours. Enter the Void is visually innovative and it obviously required quite a bit of technical know-how to get the long overhead camera runs right. But alas, all this superficial brilliance is a mere facade behind which lies hardly anything at all. This film is not anywhere near as important, intelligent or even transgressive as it seems to think. Won't be investigating the director's other efforts, either.

Review title: One of the best films I've seen in years.
Review_body: Allow me to preface this review by saying that if you are bored with the verbose, cinephile yawnfest reviews of this film, you're not the only one. I am not going to drop words like "indulgent" or compare it to Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey. Dozens of other reviewers have already done that, and to be perfectly frank, I do not agree with them. However, what I will touch upon is what many other reviewers apparently didn't grasp. First of all, I'd be willing to wager that the vast majority of them have never experimented with psychedelics (especially DMT), nor have they a background in philosophy, nor have they lived as an expatriate in a foreign land. If you are a fan of typical Hollywood blockbusters or just enjoy nice and tidy movies in which the plot is character-driven and everything logically proceeds to a predictable end, skip this film. While I do agree with many that the movie can drag on in parts, I can understand why it does so. The entire point of the flying and drifting around is to accentuate the bewilderment, isolation, and uncertainty that a disembodied soul were to experience upon death, especially within the context alluded to by reference to the Tibetan Book of the Dead. Yes, it is long. However, the film makes a deep impression and the seemingly "boring" parts are excellent for contemplation. If you have no background with hallucinogenics and are not much of a soul-searcher, you will likely think that this film is terrible. A lot of other reviewers on here think that it is far too sexually explicit,indulgent, and blatantly provocative. I disagree. I also contend that the relentless first-person perspective perfectly suits this film and feels natural. If you are uncomfortable with scenes from the film it is a clear indication that you have not experienced much in life,especially the darker aspects of living, loving, and becoming. "Enter The Void" masterfully depicts an array of feelings, ideas, and experiences that have been ignored in film or incorrectly portrayed... until now. I will say nothing more of the plot, technical wizardry, or shock factor - that has already been covered in other reviews. Needless to say, this movie is NOT for the conservative and / or closed-minded. It has been ages since a film has left such an impression on me. Yes, it is a bit bleak and disturbing, but in a good way. LIFE (for those paying attention, not dazzled by media brainwashing and / or pop culture) is disturbing, weird, and just plain unfathomable. I give this film 8/10 stars because it IS a bit too long. If some of the flying / floating in the latter half of the film were shortened or replaced with something more substantial, this flick would easily be a 9/10 or even a perfect 10/10. I cannot wait to see what Gaspar has for us next.

Review title: One of the worst films I've ever sat through.
Review_body: Save yourself the 2 and a half hour yawn-fest. This movie drags on and on and on with no point or any relevant story, which is entirely depressing, as the plot synopsis sounds great and very entertaining. If you decide to attempt sitting through this snooze-fest, prepare for non-stop camera panning and zooming as if it were shot by a first year college film student, coupled with enough color-blasting flashes and strobe-like effects to give you epileptic seizures. The acting is terrible, and I almost felt embarrassed for the actors/actresses. There are some mildly amusing CGI "trip" scenes that would probably be very interesting if you were under the influence of something, but they stretch on for far too long. As a matter of fact, this whole damn movie stretches on for FAR too long. Every thing that happens takes 10 minutes to occur. This is probably why it's a 2 and a half hour film. It takes 10 minutes for someone to even place a phone call, then (surprise!) MORE CAMERA PANNING AND ZOOMING! WOW!I get it, that it's supposed to be "artsy" and shot in 1st person as if it were through the lead character's eyes. It's not "artsy". It's repetitive, annoying, and frankly headache-inspiring. The camera does NOT need to do a full 360 and then zoom in full range in EVERY scene.The beginning half is basically a skinemax softcore porn with some neat colors and drug-use. Hooray for "art"! The second half was watchable, but barely. The cheesy camera effects never stop, not once, throughout the whole film. The characters are barely believable, and the fact that every single event takes 10 minutes to unfold does not change either. To top off all of this, I'm genuinely surprised I didn't have a seizure from all the generic strobe flashing effects. This movie is a total waste of production and viewer's time. If you want a good, intense, gritty druggy film go watch "Requiem for a Dream". This movie (Enter the Void) is garbage.

Review title: This movie will leave you thinking for days.
Review_body: I wouldn't recommend this movie for everyone, but I think everyone should at least check it out. I'm not a person who likes a lot of artsy-type movies, but I really enjoyed this movie. When I first watched it, I didn't know if this was going to be one of my favorite or least favorite movies, but after a few days, I came to the conclusion that it's one of my favorites. Some ideas were pushed a little too hard, and the ending was a little bit predictable, but I think that was intentional. The music and cinematography worked cohesively to the point where you really thought you were in the movie. I have never experienced a level of immersion quite like this.I also found it interesting that at the beginning of the movie, I felt this would be better experienced on drugs, and by the end, I don't think I'll be touching drugs for a long time.In the end, you walk away from the movie wishing there was more. Definitely different, but very interesting to watch.

Review title: The most intense movie experience ever
Review_body: The raw powerful imagery and a plethora of psychedelia that this movie throws at you isn't everyone's cup of tea and that explains the movie's dismal performance at the box office and the largely negative reception.But for those willing to experiment and are looking for an out of movie experience this movie will leave you changed. It explores the life of Oscar who lives in Tokyo dealing drugs to make a living. His friend Alex and sister Linda are against this profession of his. However, when he goes to a night club to deliver drugs to his friend Victor the police barge in and corner him in a bathroom stall. He gets shot by the police trying to flush his drugs.What follows is Oscar's out of body experience with flashbacks from his past.The movie is art in its purest, unadulterated and unrestrained form. The movie puts to film a chemical trip and goads you into thinking beyond the four walls that is your mind. It disturbs and enthralls in equal measure. If the visuals do not induce you into roller coastering I don't know what will.What this movie lacks in story or dialogue, it more than makes up for in experience. 10 out of 10 indeed.

Review title: There's a reason it was nominated for the Palme D'or at Cannes
Review_body: Unless you're an avid cinephile, the name Gaspar Noé may not mean much to you. And if you have heard of the Argentinian/French filmmaker, it's most likely because of an infamous 12-minute explicit rape scene in Irreversible, his bold 2002 experiment in reverse- chronology storytelling. Regardless of which side of the fence you fall on regarding that scene, Irreversible is undeniably a visually powerful film from an audacious auteur. Seven years later, with his first English-language feature, Enter The Void, Noé has upped the innovation ante, delivering an audio-visual masterstroke whose plot and performances - admittedly not the reason to want to watch the film - unfortunately leave something to be desired.The concept is intriguing: Oscar (newcomer Nathaniel Brown) and his sister Linda (Paz de la Huerta of HBO's Boardwalk Empire and Nurse 3D) live in Tokyo, selling drugs and stripping, respectively, to make ends meet. The catch is that we are seeing things unfold from Oscar's point of view, in the cinematic equivalent of a first-person shooter video game. When, early in Enter The Void's two-hour-and-forty-minute runtime, a drug deal goes bad and Oscar locks himself in a bar's bathroom to try and ditch the goods, we experience him getting shot and dying in the room. He sees his life, including the horrific car accident that took his parents' lives while he and his sister watch from the back seat, in a flashback sequence and then things get really strange. The camera starts floating up and away from Oscar's lifeless body, and the audience realizes that the camera has become Oscar's tortured soul. The rest of the film revolves around Oscar's soul flying over buildings, moving through walls, and entering people's bodies in an effort to come to terms with his death while making sure his sister and friends are going to be okay. It's hard to judge Brown's performance as Oscar, since we rarely see his face, but apart from newcomer Cyril Roy - who escorted a nervous friend to the audition only to be selected himself - who turns in an amusing and realistic performance as the siblings' artist friend Alex, the acting in the film is pretty 'cardboard', especially de la Huerta, who seems to only have one emotion and one facial expression regardless of whether she's mourning her brother's death, dancing for her customers, or having sex with her boss.As mentioned earlier, Enter The Void is not a film that people will watch for the story; the name itself denotes that. In an early scene, as Oscar and Alex walk to the bar discussing The Tibetan Book of the Dead and its theories of reincarnation, we already know where the film is going, structure-wise. But it's the visual and - to a lesser extent - audio presentations that make Enter The Void a film to be experienced. Noé has taken many influences, from 1947's Lady in the Lake with its first-person point of view to Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey with its tricked out visuals, not to mention the aforementioned Tibetan tome, and forged a truly unique viewing experience. Right from the frenetic, Vegas-style opening credit sequence, straight through to the final scene of Oscar's 'rebirth', the audience is in for a visual treat and will not notice that the film is over two and a half hours long. Some of what you see may need to be experienced a second time to truly appreciate the innovation that went into it. For example, in one of the few scenes in which we see Oscar's face, he's looking at himself in the mirror, and every few seconds the screen goes black for a second or so. It takes a while to realize that this isn't a glitch in the film; it's what Oscar is seeing (or not seeing) when he's blinking. It's the little tricks like this that make the high-concept Enter The Void a film well worth seeing. Docked a point for its so-so story and largely cardboard acting, Gaspar Noé's Enter The Void is still a film well worth seeing, especially for people interested in the finer points of filmmaking. There's a reason it was nominated for the Palme D'or at Cannes and that it won a special jury prize and the award for Best Cinematography (awarded to Benôit Debie) at Sitges. It's a film that is destined to be shown in college filmmaking courses for years to come. Whether you think that's a good or a bad thing will also give you your answer as to whether you might want to see it. Oh, yeah, one more thing: if your eye is quick enough to catch it during the credit sequence at the beginning of the film, that's this reviewer's son credited - albeit with his last name spelled wrong - as one of the two children who played two-year-old Oscar.

Review title: This film will change your life.
Review_body: This is the one and only film that I have ever referred to as a masterpiece. Noe's innovative vision was displayed on screen more successfully than any film you've ever seen. No director has thought this far out I the box before. The is shot from the POV of a man's soul as he experiences the steps of death according to the Tibetan Book of The Dead. This film completely changed my perspective on not only modern filmmaking, but on life. After watching the film, I felt something no film has provided before. I truly felt I got a first hand view of what happens when you die. The shots are from a completely different league. Not only are you hypnotized from the story, but the shots/changing of perspective MAKE THIS FILM A MASTERPIECE! YOU HAVE NEVER SEEN A FILM LIKE THIS BEFORE. Watch it with an open mind!To end this rant, I'd like to add that I find it ridiculous that this film wasn't given more respect/appreciation. I think the reason for this is that it was completely ahead of its time.

Review title: Amazing graphics and storyline - Would re-watch it again.
Review_body: P.S Don't watch this movie if you don't like to get really deep into movies and their meaning behind everything they show you and if you don't understand art and the abstract way of showing thing.My friend advised me this movie. I really liked the mood and the quality of it. The graphics were really great, but I advise not to watch it while being sober. Watch it while you're high, the effects will look a lot better and it will be easier to understand the meaning of this film. And also watch it with someone who really loves to get into long talks about life and just philosophy in general, as there's so much to talk about. While watching it sober, it kind of got really tiring at the end, or it just may be my little attention span. I really loved the philosophical meaning, about reincarnation and life on the other side aka what happens when we die. Eastern culture, has always interested me, because there's something magical about it. I'd definitely re-watch this movie again and again, as there's so much to see in it, that watching it once doesn't even do the justice.I'm giving it 9 out of 10, because I think this movie is a masterpiece.

Review title: intended to be deep but ending up being a long torture
Review_body: Don't get me wrong, the visuals are amazing but in the end it's just a movie for pseudo intellectuals who think being tortured by a director is deep and brings a broader understanding of life, art, etc. If you enjoyed this you probably are masochist. The same thing could have been done without having to stab you in the heart emotionally. In the end it's just 2 hours of shock therapy and emotional distress with trippy visuals. Please be aware that if you have any history of epilepsy this movie can be quite dangerous. The director intently uses flashy colors and and strobe light effects to enhance the visual experience. Even if you are not epileptic you may end up having a headache.

Review title: The single worst movie I have ever seen
Review_body: Let me preface by saying I've seen thousands of movies. I've seen many of the movies often regarded as the worst. Plan 9, the room, Tarzoon, underground comedy, puppet master sequels, paranormal activity sequels, an American Hippie in Israel, highlander 2, Catwoman etc. I've seen almost every Adam Sandler film and Steven Seagal, every rob Schneider, Nick Cage, Pauly Shore, and Van Damme. Obscure gay independent films and films meant to create a state of mind like being on drugs. My point is that I have every basis for comparison when I say the following: Enter the Void is by far the worst movie I have ever seen. It has no redeeming qualities. From the Bafflingly awful direction to Weaponized dialogue used to attack the audience all the way to the twist at the end, only surprising inasmuch as you wouldn't believe someone would have the balls to make it that lame and uninteresting. The bizarre birds eye shots and shifts in camera angle give the viewer the impression that this was not really a movie. Not so much as an art project for students wanting to reproduce the effects of torture. It is not bad in a fun way, it is not campy, it is not ironic. It is just painful. Worth seeing only to calibrate your opinion of all other movies. This is bedrock with nowhere to go but up. If a perfect movie were a 10 then enter the void would define 0. Unfortunately the system won't let me rate that low.

Holy F*cking Sh*t Balls...Not really a review. More like gushing fan mail. I don't have enough superlatives to describe how visceral and real this is(on one hand) and completely out there on another(hand). How ever trippy it is, what really moved me was how REAL some things felt.It was awesome to see Tokyo 'behind the scenes', all messed up, pimpy and dirty as hell. It's a breath of fresh air to see a major city for what it is(actually);a cesspool of too many people occupying the same piece of land. Hollywood always likes to employ the 'best of tourism pics' when it shoots something on location-this film, shows you the mould growing on everything.The high rise drug dens and neon sex clubs and the way they are portrayed make you feel as if you are about to catch a venereal disease on your eye balls.The long trip scenes and uncomfortable flights over the city(and inside it-LOL) almost make you wonder if the afterlife exists and if Gaspar Noe was somehow privy to it-it almost made me believe in a god.What I enjoyed most is how the gritty, real elements of the film flow into this drug fuelled, afterlife fantasia and the effect it had on me. The first time I watched this film I had a full blown panic attack, imagining what my own death would be like and the experience stayed with me weeks after. I love a film that gets under your skin and changes you(they are so rare).Noe has the courage to show life without the trappings of the romantic age:the world, for the most part, is not a pretty place and more often than not there is some f*cked up sh*t going on somewhere. Even when I watched his more recent film 'Love' I got the same impression:THIS is real life.As such it wont make you feel good or comfortable or happy but even so, one can't help feeling that this film is nothing short of a pure affirmation of life.Whatever your tastes, if you haven't seen this or one of his other films, you just don't have a conception of what cinema could be in the modern age.Well worth it's extended run time.
