Enter the Void finally made it to a week-long limited showing at a theater in Atlanta, so naturally a group of my close friends and I set out to see it for my friend's birthday.Many people have criticized it for being too drawn out, too sexually explicit, and overly confusing for the sake of being trippy. I disagree with all these things and feel that, having experienced the world through psychedelics and having seen the dark kind of underground portrayed in this film, that its dreamlike, sinister, and scattered narrative is appropriate.I also feel that it's a film that you really need to sit through and pay close attention to. It has a lot of very powerful and controversial messages to throw at the audience, and those easily offended might have trouble looking past this instead of understanding their place in the context of the story. After all, the end, to me, is beautiful and makes the rest of the film worth it.As pretty much everyone seems to agree upon, the visual aspect of the film is just breathtaking. One particular scene toward the end is the best depiction of what the world looks like while tripping that I've ever seen. Beyond the psychedelic imagery, the whole movie is just pure eye candy.In short, it may be challenging to some but if you really watch through it it's a phenomenally profound and rewarding journey that has you leaving the theater in a trance, pondering deep philosophical questions.
What makes interesting to watch Gasper Noe movies is his art of breaking the current wave of movie forms. Enter the void is surely his masterpiece.

Never before had I walked out of a movie theatre. But this movie proved to be such an enormous amount of pretentious negative BS that I decided to stop being polite and respectful. This flick didn't deserve that. Not my attention, nor my time. Not my money too, but alas, too late. I was told that the movie cost 24 million to make and grossed only 1 million. So justice is already there.The plot is made up of pseudo-spiritual drivel. Thin as the ice on a lake after one night of frost. And it's all explained in one the first scenes of the movie. So as an audience member you must sit through more than two and a half hours of grueling and totally predictable clichés, watching this tiny plot unravel as was predicted by one of the characters. How deep it all is!That's my main problem with this particular piece of sick "art": the suggestion of deepness. Deep thoughts, rich symbolism, intangibility and mystery, rawness and confrontation, life and death. Plus an overwhelming array of startling and bewildering images (and sound effects).What is actually offered instead, when you look past the charade, is a so very often depicted world of drug users and whores, living on the edge in some metropolis somewhere in the world. Superficial and bent on shocking the audience. Nothing deep about that. It's like Hollywood with sour popcorn.
Simply distasteful. And nothing new.The moment I chose to walk away from all that was when I saw child actors (really young) obviously being abused to serve the director's sick purpose. 
Now THAT I couldn't and wouldn't take anymore.I can't believe that anyone with a keen eye is willing to swallow such utter nonsense which isn't even worthy of the moniker "film". It's rather an abuse of that medium, I find. May the director soon be cured of his mental ills so he won't bother movie-goers much longer. That would be my advice (maybe Lars "von" Trier can join him, another troubled man of the same kind, in my mind).Enter The Void, it's quite an apt title. Devoid of real meaning, only smoke and mirrors, very cheap.
No, I didn't enter. I left. Goodbye.

Review title: A window into an existential realm you never knew existed!
Review_body: I will preface this 'critique' with the caveat that this is the first review I have written and my viewing of this title was a few year ago... I am by no means a 'movie buff' however "Enter the Void" still grips me to this day and obviously enough to elicit the writing of this review...I was first captivated by 'Enter the Void' after seeing short bursts of this film on Foxtel. After the initial fascination I knew it was a movie I had to save for later viewing and subsequently switched channels and put it to the back of my consciousness. Sometime later I revisited the thought of watching this movie and decided to do a little investigation on IMDB, subsequently learning it was a movie by Gasper Noe of "Irreversible" fame; my interest peaked to say the least! Intuitively I knew this was not a movie per say but instead a portal into the patchwork of an alternate reality! This really is a movie that you NEED to set your mind and environment for in order to appreciate the underlying fabric of this 'film'. Enter the Void is NOT a movie you just switch on and watch; it is an experience that you build yourself up to and only then can you hope to strap yourself in an enjoy the ride! I cannot vehemently state this enough! My ideal surroundings for viewing this film would be solitude, introspection, the cover of darkness, and some wine! Everyone is different but I hope you get my drift.As other reviewers have eluded to this is a film with Buddhist undertones and my humble suggestion would be to engage in 'mindfulness' and just let the movie take control and override your senses. Trust me you will be rewarded with an experience that will colour your psyche and give a unique insight into the existential notions of life. It will have you thinking about the meaning of your life and this truly can be an overwhelming experience. It brought out many emotions in me that still stick with me to this day and to be honest I don't know if I have the emotional strength to withstand a second viewing despite my curiosity of going deeper into the void.Others have pointed out the licentious undertone of many characters in this film, and the heavy darkness this bequest upon them on viewing. However, and in the hope of sallying forth, I do not believe a 'nihilist' framework as portrayed by the protagonist in this movie is 'negative' or perhaps counter intuitively devoid of emotion and worth; I believe it allows for a deeper examination of our being in this expansive world and whatever conclusions you arrive at they are all positive and genuine; nothing can be more comforting than having a grasp on reality however difficult it may be. This is a matter for philosophical debate however I am merely pointing our the emotions this movie can stir within you.As I am sure you have gathered this movie covers vast expanses of human nature and considering this it really is impossible to get everything right regarding character development and general directional constructs ect. For example in my view some of the relationship boundaries were exaggerated and could have been toned down a notch particularly with the brother sister dynamic. However, one cannot expect perfection especially when considering the depth of this movies content. I will briefly say that In my opinion all the characters did a marvellous job and it really is refreshing to see new and 'raw' faces that buy into Gasper Noes vision so selflessly. There are scenes in this film I will never forget especially the grungy 'toilet scene' which precedes the deliverance into he void as well as some of the dialogue between the protagonist and his sister and best friend Alex. the Special mention to the little girl in some of the scenes; I can honestly say her portrayal was hauntingly realistic to the point it was disturbing and infinitely memorable. Further the sounds and impulses generated by the musical score and idiosyncratic camera angles give a lasting impression of the underbelly of the setting in Tokyo.All in all an absolute masterpiece in my view and one that no matter your opinion is really a must watch at least once in your life. Kudos to all involved and thank-you for the trip into the void!
